thread.title_full: Watch out for printer scam where fraudster steal details | Daily Mail Online

author: Lee Boyce for Thisismoney.co.uk
title: Watch out for printer scam where fraudster steal details
text:
A new financial scam has emerged that involves fraudsters targetting households that call helplines with printer problems, according to National Trading Standards.
The printer helpline scam differs from most others, Trading Standards says, as victims are lured into contacting the criminals rather than the other way around.
Victims usually come across the 'helpline' numbers on online adverts placed high on search engines or social media which are actually fake.
Printer panic: According to Trading Standards, there has been a sharp rise in so-called printer scams
In one case, they tried to charge a victim £700 after he called a helpline, while another was told their identity and passwords had been stolen and a £200 fee was required to correct it.
Cases seen by the Trading Standard eCrime team have involved those behind the 'helplines' gaining remote access to people's computers – under the guise of helping them resolve their technical problems – only for them to steal personal information including bank account details and infect computers with malware.
HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP Beat the scammers: The new hub page from This is Money with the latest scams One particular group behind these scams, which claims to be affiliated with a wide range of technology brands and printer manufacturers, holds victims to ransom by taking control of their computers before demanding payment to return control.
Figures from Action Fraud, the national reporting centre for fraud and cybercrime, reveal that cases such as computer service fraud, which encompasses scams such this, have nearly doubled since 2014, with a total of 32,719 cases being seen in 2016.
Mike Andrews, lead co-ordinator of the National Trading Standards eCrime Team said: 'This printer helpline scam is particularly pernicious because it encourages victims to unknowingly contact the fraudsters of their own accord.
'While victims expect they will receive help with their printer problems they have in fact been lured into a trap and find themselves at risking of losing money, important personal information and also have their computer security compromised.'
Lord Toby Harris, chair of National Trading Standards, said: 'I would urge people to be particularly vigilant about this scam.
'If you are seeking help for printer issues you should always use the official printer helpline details provided when you bought the product or consult the official website of the manufacturer for helpline details.'
In October 2015, This is Money warned of a similar type of scam where a growing army of fraudsters were calling unassuming computer users pretending to be from software giant Microsoft , who then demand cash to remove 'viruses,' according to official fraud data.
One reader lost £480 to the scam, after receiving a phone call from a man claiming to be from Microsoft.
He said her computer urgently needed virus-protection software. She said he was 'persistent and intimidating.' He persuaded Susan to download software to allow him to log-on and control her computer remotely.
HOW TO PROTECT YOURSELF FROM THE PRINTER SCAM National Trading Standards is advising people take the following steps:
- When seeking technical support for your printer, make sure you use the contact details provided by the printer manufacturer. These can be found by visiting the manufacturer's official website, listed on its product packaging and literature.
- Be suspicious of helplines asking to take remote control of your computer to fix printer problems.
- Make sure that your anti-virus and online security software is kept up-to-date, to reduce the risk of unwanted pop-ups on-screen that may advertise fraudulent services
